narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We used MWF synchronous class learning and Sra. Reymundi recorded videos for T, TH classes to be viewed at any point during the day.
Virtual section, in a lecture and seminar/discussion format
We had two asynchronous classes per week.
There were also asynchronous lectures.
We also learned asynchronously, and that was basically self-learning/teaching.
n/a

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My conversational Spanish skills improved the most dramatically through this course. I gained more confidence to speak in front of my peers in Spanish. Prior to the class, I was very shy and never wanted to speak in Spanish in front of peers/a teacher. My ability to write using different verb tenses and using connection words increased as well.
Intermediate knowledge of Spanish, basic and intermediate forms of Spanish vocabulary, reading comprehension of Spanish texts, conversations in Spanish
I have improved in reading and writing Spanish.
I learned how to use the grammar skills we learned in real-life conversations through many breakout room discussions.

I learned how to conjugate verbs in Spanish in many different tenses, and I also learned to speak Spanish more fluently through listening to Spanish music and watching Spanish film. It was very helpful that we had to speak mainly in Spanish during class.

I deepened my understanding of the Spanish language, particularly complicated grammar structures and conversational Spanish. I learned about the significance of both the Spanish language and culture to global history.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is fantastic at introducing students to L-3 Spanish. The use of Supersite, the textbook, speaking in class, and documents was amazing and engaging. I would most certainly recommend this class.

Strengths: Reymundi was awesome, definitely explained some tough concepts pretty well. Conversations with peers was definitely one of the higher points of the course, allowing to practice speaking but also getting to know classmates. Homeworks and quizzes weren't terrible, and the exams and writing assignments weren't too bad either. If you set aside a decent amount of time after class to dedicate to improving Spanish with what was learned in class, this class definitely helped with that. Weaknesses: Felt like there was an over reliance on the site used for some practice problems. The book assigned for the class was also sped through very quickly without a lot of time to really enjoy it. Something that could be improved is more oral activities as well as more practice problems specifically geared to the concepts taught in the class itself.
I think it might be helpful to focus on speaking more often. I felt a bit underprepared for my oral exam.

I appreciated the daily tasks, which helped me practice this language even on days without class. A weakness, though, was that some tasks just seemed like busywork that didnt really help me understand the language better.

Strength: Professor Reymundi herself makes the course 1000 times better. She is so understanding, kind, and patient with her students. Weakness: I think the online platform is the weakness in the fact that I love speaking and getting to know all my classmates individually but it was hard to do so given that the class times were so short. But Professor Reymundi did try to facilitate that by putting us into breakout rooms.

This class was very well-structured, giving much opportunity for daily Spanish practice and improvement. After the first wave of quizzes/exams, students know what to expect for the rest of the semester; there aren't many surprises which makes the workload more manageable.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: At this time, I cannot think of a way this course could be improved. I loved the use fo breakout rooms to facilitate talking to peers in class. The way this course was engineered so rapidly for online-learning amazes me.
The instructor was very intentional and experienced when it came to Zoom best practices.
I think having 3 zoom classes per week was an effective approach. Supersite was also a valuable tool for remote learning.

The breakout room discussions were really beneficial in preparing me for the oral exam. However, there were some technological issues (which made it hard on test-days when it infringed upon our test-taking time).

Having students engage in the online platform was a success, since we were often put into breakout rooms to discuss and speak in Spanish together. One thing that could be improved, however, was a clarity on what assignments were due and what we had to prepare for the next class. I was often confused if assignments were in my canvas section or on the umbrella section.

Adapting the previous daily classes to the three synchronous and two asynchronous classes per week was very helpful in managing the workload associated with this course. Additionally, retaining small class sizes was integral to comfortable language learning. There are no practices that were particularly unsuccessful in this course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to any student who wishes to see their Spanish speaking, reading, and writing skills improved drastically. I never imagined I would be able to read a Spanish short story prior to taking this class. By the end, I enjoyed reviewing the short story to prepare for the last examen.
I would recommend this course because I do think I improved my Spanish throughout the semester.
I would definitely recommend the class! In high school, the way we learned Spanish promoted memorization, but this class actually helped me speak and understand the language better.
Yes! definitely, if you want to improve your Spanish, go for it!

Absolutely! I really enjoyed this class, not only because I am fascinated my language learning, but more so because it offered a great opportunity to build virtual community. Unlike larger lecture courses, this course provided an intimate and comfortable environment to learn the Spanish language as well as engage with peers/professors.
